description:
This BBC Micro version of Revs is the initial release of this Formula Three racing game. It only contains the Silverstone track. Players can do practice rounds on the track or participate in a championship, preceded by qualifying laps to determine the starting position. There are three difficulty levels to choose from and in the pits the front and rear wing settings can be changed.

Controlling the car is more complex than contemporary titles, with different keys for the gears, one for the gas and additional one to accelerate. It is also a pure simulation, much in the spirit of Geoff Crammond's later Grand Prix series; every contact with another car or missing a corner almost immediately leads to a crash.
title: Revs

description: Fortress is a clone of SEGA's Zaxxon, copying many elements of the original game. Using a scrolling isometric perspective, players need to guide a space ship through a course. It is filled with enemies such as stationary turrets, space ships and rockets launching from the ground. There are also many obstacles that need to be avoided. Instead of merely shooting anything that moves the player also needs to shoot fuel barrels to combat the dwindling fuel supply. The ship is also able to move up and down into the air. That way many hazards can be avoided, but it consumes a lot of fuel. Flying higher is often needed to move over walls and pass through narrow gates. When the game is completed it immediately restarts. The player has three lives.

sample_screenshots.caption: Lift off to pass this wall
This is a dreaded part where you have to aim carefully to fit through the gate.

title: Fortress

description:
Events in the rural village of Ambridge have enthralled BBC Radio 4 listeners since 1950. The computer game re-creation casts you as one of the scriptwriters. The game is split into four parts, in which you control Jack Woolley, Elizabeth Archer, Eddie Grundy and Nelson Gabriel in turn. Guide each character through their decisions (from 3 multiple-choices), with the aim of choosing the most listener-friendly choices. Your choices affect the show's rating directly, as well as changing the forthcoming plot much more than in The Secret Diary of Adrian Mole Aged 13¾.

Characters can be removed from the show depending on how you develop certain storylines, but make sure not to axe the popular ones. Avoid offending special-interest groups, as the BBC comes down hard on writers who generate complaints.

Unlike the other versions of this game the BBC version is the only one that comes without graphics, hence it is pure interactive fiction and text adventure, although the input is actually rather limited to choosing answers from multiple choice type questions to progress in the story than typing in commands of one's own choice and finding out how to solve puzzles to go further. The four parts of the game are evenly spread on both sides of the cassette tape. Each of the sides contains two parts of the story.
title: The Archers

description: You must ride your moon cycle across the surface of a choice of three moons, avoiding boulders, bouncing monsters, oncoming barrels and bombs dropped by overhead space ships. You are equipped with a moon gun, which fires simultaneously vertically and horizontally. Boulders can be shot to make jumping over them easier but firing into the ground creates craters, as do bombs dropped from above, these craters must be jumped over or a life is lost and the more difficult the moon the more rugged the landscape, so you'll have to be careful when firing.
title: BMX on the Moon

description:
This first licensed game based on the longest-running television sci-fi series (starting in 1963) features the fifth doctor, Peter Davidson, on the cover. The doctor is a humanoid alien who travels through space and time on the TARDIS, which appears on the outside as a blue 1950s British police box. You must create a time key and take it to the centre of the universe to create "the second age of time". This has to be done within a time limit of an hour through four different sections which are variations on popular early video games.

  • The Labyrinth of Death is a Pac-Man clone where you must collect three pieces of the time key while avoiding enemies - the evil weevils of Ourouborous Vl.

  • The Prison is a Frogger-like game where you must get from the bottom to the top of the screen while avoiding various enemies or jump on objects to cross water.

  • The Terrordactyls is similar to the arcade game Phoenix where you are a space ship at bottom of screen shooting at winged enemies above. Shooting a whole wave of enemies will move your ship higher on the screen.

  • The Box of Tantalus is a Battleship clone where you cross the mysterious Box of Tantalus (Minor) in space and must find and destroy the invisible monsters who lurk there.
title: Doctor Who: The First Adventure

description:
This second licensed game based on the Doctor Who sci-fi television series is a text adventure.

In the first part, you are looking for the Doctor on a strange planet where you encounter androids, interstellar gypsies and King Varangar's moody blood guards. You must obtain information through conversations and exploring areas by typing various text commands. Objects must also be collected in order to complete the game.

In the second part, you travel in the Tardis back in time to the Battle Of Waterloo where you must defeat both Napoleon and the evil Warlord.

There are 250 different locations in each part.
title: Doctor Who and the Warlord

description:
Long ago, the normally peaceful land of Wizadore was invaded by the evil dragon Smaun. The arch mage of the land constructed a magical sword to help defeat the foul wyrm, but during the attempt the sword was smashed and broken into three pieces. Now, decades later, the mage's grandson sets out to roam the land, find the three pieces of the sword, and put it together again to finally defeat the beast.

The player controls the young mage on his quest in this side-scrolling platformer. The pieces of the sword are scattered all over Wizadore, which consists of a large number of screens, set over different levels connected by stairs. Hindering the mage's exploration of the surroundings (involving ladder-climbing and gap-jumping) are guards, armed with axes or bows and arrows; some of them even ride flying creatures. At the beginning, the mage is helpless, but on the way he can pick up magical scrolls which allow him to cast spells (like lightning or fire) to crush the opposition.

sample_screenshots.caption: There are dungeons below the ground.
Avoiding bad guys by sneaking down the ladder.

title: Wizadore

description: Atomic Protector is a fast-paced arcade title, like Pac-Man but in reverse. The player (a robot in charge of a uranium deposit invaded by aliens) this time has to protect already laid down dots on the map instead of picking them up. The enemies are of two kinds: One will run around the map, picking up all the dots. If all dots are taken, the game is over. If there are remaining dots when the time is out, the level is completed and the game progresses to a faster, more difficult level. In order to protect the dots, the player may bump into this enemy, sending it the other way, or he may set up a portable wall to seal off the enemy's path. The other kind is radioactive, and a staggering warning tone sounds as it enters the maze. It must be caught before it contaminates you. Each new level is faster, and more challenges are added.

sample_screenshots.caption: Hardly any dots left, and you're distracted by the radioactive being
This bell thing at the bottom is a radioactive alien which must be caught
Ram the enemy to protect the dots
You didn't catch it on time and you die

title: Atomic Protector

description:
Space Pilot is a clone of the classic Konami game Time Pilot and was developed independently from the contemporary C64 game of the same name with similar gameplay. Players command an aircraft through different environments, shooting down planes to collect points. The ship's nose can be rotated left or right, so the craft can move into any direction and take sharp turns left or right. Speed is not controlled by the user and it is always maintained at the same level automatically. The background is wrapped endlessly both horizontally and vertically, and that way it is impossible to encounter a border. The game takes place in five time periods: 1916, 1940, 1970, 1984 and 1999. Each level holds different types of enemies, from classic biplanes to spitfires, helicopters, jets and UFOs.

In each scene the player needs to shoot eight regular planes to decrease an icon bar of planes in the top left corner. For every icon that disappears a sound is played and a new squadron arrives. Once all the icons are gone a large boss ship appears and it takes multiple hits to destroy it. After taking it out the plane travels through time to a new period. The player's aircraft has an unlimited amount of bullets. Enemy planes have bullets too, but some of them can also drop bombs or fire homing missiles. In certain environments paratroopers with a red cross appear; these can be collected for bonus points. There are four lives in total before the game is over, but for every 10,000 points a new life is granted. No more than five lives can be held. When all time periods have been completed, the cycle of the five scenes is restarted, but the score is kept.

sample_screenshots.caption: In the second time period you fight spitfires.
Fighting the blimp, the first boss
Start of the first time period

title: Space Pilot

description:
Welcome is a collection of software published by the British Broadcasting Corporation. It comprises sixteen separate programs designed to introduce the user to the BBC computer and really simple computing concepts. Within this compilation of educational software are the games Sketch, Kingdom and Bat 'n 'Ball.

The software was packaged with the BBC Micro and was part of a larger project, commissioned by the BBC and the UK Government's Microelectronics and Education programme, which included 'The Computer Programme' television series, books, a course in BASIC programming and a postal helpline.

The full contents of the compilation are:

  • Program 1: Welcome

This helps the user to set the volume control on their cassette player, essential for loading programs, and goes on to demonstrate the computers sound & graphics capabilities.

  • Program 2: Index

Lists the contents of the cassette and can be used to load the other programs.

  • Program 3: Keyboard

This program teaches the user how to use a keyboard and introduces the Shift, Shift Lock & Caps Lock keys. There are five tests and a score is given at the end of each.

  • Program 4: Sketch

The player is presented a blank screen in the centre of which is a flashing dot. Pictures can be drawn by moving the dot around the screen using the arrows. This game introduces the player to the BBC's user-definable keys which are used to change the colour of the line being drawn.

  • Program 5: A calculator.
  • Program 6: Alphasort

This is designed to show how a computer can save time & money by performing tedious tasks. The user enters ten words and the computer sorts them into order.

  • Program 7: Poem

A specially commissioned poem with graphics by Roger McGough.

  • Program 8: Telephone

This is a simple searchable database of people and their telephone numbers.

  • Program 9: Bat 'n 'Ball

This is a single-player game based on squash. A ball bounces off the back wall of the play area, and the player must manoeuvre a bat in order to keep the ball in play. The length of the play area decreases as the game progresses, this decreases the ball's travel time thus making the game faster and faster.

  • Program 10: Music

Each key on the keyboard plays a musical note when pressed.

  • Program 11: A clock.
  • Program 12: Photo

Here the program demonstrates its graphic capabilities by drawing a picture of a face, famous in 1981, from a series of straight lines.

  • Program 13: Patterns

Displays on screen a kaleidoscope that changes when keys are pressed.

  • Program 14: Kingdom

This is a resource management game also known as The Yellow River Kingdom Game and is a conversion of the game Hamurabi.

The player takes the role of ruler of a small kingdom and in each round / turn must decide how many acres of land to buy or sell, how many bushels of grain to feed the population with, and how much grain to plant. Each decision affects the state of the kingdom as do randomly occurring events such as disasters, weather, etc.

  • Program 15: Biorhythms

Based on the assumption that biorhythms run in fixed cycles that start at birth, this program has the user enter their date of birth so that it can predict their biorhythms on any subsequent date.

  • Program 16: Message

This gives information about other parts of the BBC Computer Literacy Project.

sample_screenshots.caption: Yellow River Kingdom. A simple strategy game.
If the ball hits the bottom of the screen, the game is over.
Loading screen graphic. This is the disc version.

title: Welcome

description: Attack on Alpha Centauri is a fixed screen shoot 'em up similar to Galaxian. Alpha Centauri is being attacked by enormous wasps. They swarm over the planet while dropping devastating bombs onto it. The player has to try and kill as many as he can before his inevitable death. The game plays like other shoot em 'ups of the early eighties. The player moves their spacecraft left and right along the bottom of the screen while shooting at the rows of wasps above them. The wasps start in stationary positions at the top but as time goes they take turns and move down towards the player and drop bombs. When all the wasps has been killed off they are replaced with a new and harder wave and the game goes on until the player has lost all their three lives. Points are given for each killed enemy. Stationary enemies are worth ten points while the flying ones are worth a hundred.

sample_screenshots.caption: Third wave - more bugs attack for each wave
The bugs attack one at a time
I got hit and lost a life

title: Attack on Alpha Centauri

description: Transistors Revenge is a game that not only runs on the BBC Micro, it also takes place in it. The computer's CPU is under attack and it is up to the player to defend it. Other components such as resistors, transistors, capacitors, diodes and fuses have become jealous of the processor's elevated position in the computer. The gameplay can be described as similar to a two dimensional variant of Tempest. The player has a top down view of the the circuit board, with the CPU in the middle and data lines going outwards from it. The enemies will follow these lines till they reach the CPU and the player's task is to stop them by shooting out electrical pulses down the data lines. If any of the enemies reach the CPU it will explode and the player will lose a life. At times different tools such as hammers and pliers appear briefly and shooting these will give some bonus points. In addition to the ordinary fire the player also has access to a powerful zap attack that kills everything on the screen. It can't be used freely though as it will need some time to recover after being used.

sample_screenshots.caption: The track design changes after a while
Hit the hammer for bonus points
The CPU explodes when the components reach it

title: Transistors Revenge

description:
Repton: The Lost Realms was originally meant as a sequel to Repton 3 but was ultimately not released until more than twenty years later. It is also most similar to that game, with the basic gameplay remaining the same. The game consists of 24 levels and the objective of each is to defuse a number of time bombs. Before this can be done however the player has to collect all diamonds and golden crowns and kill all monsters. Failing to do this within a certain time will result in the bombs exploding and the player loses a life. There are a number of puzzles that has to be solved and everything has to be done in a certain order or else the player may block himself in. Therefore it's necessary to plan ahead and pick the right route. As usually the player has to watch out for falling boulders as well as monsters, spirits, skulls and fungus. In addition to boulders this game also features balloons that are equally lethal but floats upwards. There are also certain doors that the player can remove only by collecting absorbalene pills.

An editor is included with the game. It allows the player to modify characters and levels.
title: Repton: The Lost Realms

description: Alien Swirl is a fixed screen shoot 'em up in the style of Moon Cresta and Phoenix. Players control their ship down the base line and have to shoot at the aliens swirling around above them. There are a number of aliens for each stage and the player has to shoot them all down to move on to the next stage. The first wave has only three aliens but as the player progresses through the waves the number of aliens increases. There is also a mother ship similarly to the one in Space Invaders that occasionally moves across the screen. After every four waves there is a refuelling stage where the player has to dock his or her ship with a tanker. This works similar to Lunar Lander. Bonus points are awarded depending on how well this is done and at every 10000 points the player earns a bonus life.

sample_screenshots.caption: More aliens gets added for each wave
After four waves it's time to refuel
Trying to descend to the tanker

title: Alien Swirl

description:
No relation to the more well-known arcade adventure, Sorcery for the BBC is an arcade platformer in the same vein as Donkey Kong. You, in the shape of a hooded swordsman, must climb four floors of platforms to reach an evil magician who has taken your wife captive. While there are only four stairs to scale, it is a difficult task because of the ghosts, fire-breathing birds, arrows and flying magical balls. You must alternate between using your sword or jumping across them, or fooling the ghosts by going to a lower platform, then up again.

One peculiarity about Sorcery is that if you are hit, you don't immediately lose your life. Instead, you are transformed into a frog, sitting at the bottom of the screen, and your wife is given the opportunity to climb down to the bottom to free you from the spell.

sample_screenshots.caption: The first platform has been scaled
Your only choice is to kill the bird with your sword before it unleashes its fiery breath
The magician turns a bird into a ghost

title: Sorcery

description: Super Invaders is a Space Invaders variant. The player controls his defender ship left and right and has to prevent aliens from landing by shooting at them. Some protection is offered by four bastions which can take some shots before being destroyed. This version of the game offers three different difficulties with the harder ones offering some additional gameplay features. The easier one, A Mild Encounter, plays like traditional Space Invaders. In the Uncomfortable Situation difficulty the UFO, when it survives without being shot, produces a force shield that guides the aliens and hastens their speed. The hard mode is called A Terrifying Experience and here the alien projectiles have a homing capability and follow the player. There are three different kinds of aliens and they are scored depending on how far from the player they are. The player has three lives and an extra is earned after 5000 and 15000 points.
title: Super Invaders

description: Rocket Raid is a side scrolling shoot 'em up and a variant of Scramble. The player has to fly his space craft through a cave that consists of five sections each with different hazards and enemies. Enemies include rockets launching from the ground, small green aliens and indestructible meteoroids that have to be dodged. There are two weapons to use: a gun that shoots forward and bombs that can be dropped on building on the ground. The player has three lives but can earn more by reaching certain scores.

sample_screenshots.caption: Try to shoot down the launching rockets

title: Rocket Raid

description: Meteor Mission is a Lunar Rescue variant. The player controls an emergency space capsule which has be to be used to rescue six astronauts stranded on an alien planet. The player starts in a mothership at the top of the screen from which he has to descend down to the surface where the astronauts are waiting. But to succeed he has to navigate his way through a field of meteors and land on one of two platforms at the surface. The player can control the capsule left and right and use thrust to slow down the speed. In addition to the meteors there is also an alien pursuit ship that launches missiles at the player. Once an astronaut has entered the capsule it's time to go back up. Unlike the original arcade game it's the same field of meteors that the player has to move through. The player can now use a gun to shoot at the meteors. When all six astronauts have been rescued the player gets a bonus and moves on to the next level.

sample_screenshots.caption: Going back up - now we can shoot

title: Meteor Mission

description: Four men are stranded on the side of an erupting volcano and it's up to the player to rescue them with his emergency helicopter. Volcano consists of a single side view screen where the crater is located in the middle, the helicopter's landing platform on the right and the men to be rescued on the left. What the player has to do is fly over the volcano, pick up the men one at a time and return them to the platform. This is not an easy task since a large amount of boulder are hurled from the crater and these have to be either shot or avoided. Touching a boulder or crashing into the ground will lead to the helicopter being destroyed and the player loses one life. As if this isn't enough the player has to work quickly since molten lava is pouring from the mouth of the volcano down towards the stranded men. If a man dies he will turn into a ghost which will go after the player. Ghosts have to be avoided since they are indestructible. The player has three helicopters and gets an extra one after 5,000 points scored.

sample_screenshots.caption: Dead men turns into ghosts which can't be killed
Navigating through the boulders is almost like bullet hell
Oh no, poor guy is dropped to his death

title: Volcano

description: Crazy Painter is a clone of Amidar. It initially had the same name, but was renamed to avoid legal difficulties before its release by Superior. The player controls a creature and needs to paint levels divided into rectangles of various sizes. They are painted by moving over the bordering edges, colouring them. When a rectangle is traced entirely, it is filled with a colour. Meanwhile enemies that roam the edges need to be avoided. There is also a limited amount of jumps used to get out of tricky situations. The character has a number of lives and the game keeps tracks of the score.

sample_screenshots.caption: Run about the level, painting lines and avoiding the enemies.
Blocks will fill in with solid color when you have painted all of their sides.

title: Crazy Painter

description: Tetrapod is an arena shooter with controls similar to Asteroids, with the player being able to move forward, shoot and rotate left and right. For every stage the player has to defeat a number of creatures ranging from killer bees in early levels to red devils and poison orbs in later ones. What makes this more complicated is that the screen is full of pods that when shot at hatches a lizard that immediately goes after the creature closest to it, no matter if that is the player or one of the enemies. Killer bees can be killed by a direct hit from the player while the other creatures can only be killed by the lizards. The player should avoid hitting them since they will then chase him more intently. Lizards can not be killed but when shot at they will turn back into their original pod form. Shots fired will bounce around the screen until hitting something. This include the player so the player not only has to watch out for enemies and their fire but his own bullets too.
title: Tetrapod

description:
The Gold Collection is a compilation that includes the following games:

  • Jetpac
  • Knight Lore
  • Night Shade
  • Sabre Wulf
  • Pirate Adventure
  • Voodoo Castle
  • Strange Odyssey
  • Buckaroo Banzai
  • Temple of Terror
title: The Gold Collection

description:
Carousel is a clone of the arcade game Carnival which is a fixed screen shoot 'em up with an amusement park theme. The player controls a gun down the bottom of the screen and has to shoot the targets that move back and forth above him or her in three rows. The player has a limited amount of bullets and when out of them the game ends. The targets are made up of three different animals: ducks, rabbits and owls as well as letters of the word BONUS. Hit the letters in the correct order and a bonus score is given for each. Ducks are special as they might swoop down towards the player and the player has to shoot them before they land or else he or she will lose bullets.

In addition to the targets there is also a rotating wheel at the top of the screen and all of its spokes have to be shot to complete a level. Once everything on the screen has been shot, the player moves on to a bonus round featuring a polar bear. It will move across the screen and the player has to shoot it as many times as possible. For every hit the bear reverses his direction and increases his speed until it escapes and the player moves on to the next level.

sample_screenshots.caption: Later the bear is accompanied by a duck

title: Carousel

description: Cube Master is a digital version of the Rubik's Cube puzzle game. The screen is split in two areas. Bottom half has a graphical presentation of the cube viewed from two different perspectives with all of its faces visible. The top half is used to enter text commands to interact with the cube. Each face has a letter and by entering it that face is turned 90 degrees clockwise while entering it with shift held down turns it 90 degrees anti-clockwise. To scramble the cube the player enters X followed by the number of moves to shuffle. It's also possible to have the computer solve the cube by typing S. There's also a feature for the player to draw a custom cube by entering the colour wanted for each square.

sample_screenshots.caption: It did it in the end
Playing around with the cube by entering commands

title: Cube Master

description:
Sliding-Block Puzzles consists of six different pictures with 25 pieces:

  • Alphabet
  • Numbers
  • Sunscape
  • Logo
  • Pattern
  • Swans

When starting out the player gets to enter the number of shuffling moves wanted (from 2 to 511). Once the picture has been shuffled, the player uses the keyboard cursor keys to move around the square cursor over the pieces of the picture. When pressing the return key, the pieces are slid into the open space. It's possible to slide up to four pieces at once. If stuck it's possible to allow the computer to complete the puzzle by typing S.
title: Sliding-Block Puzzles

description: The Wizard is an action game where the player takes control of said wizard. It all happens by a sea where five princesses are located on five islands while the wizard stands on a cliff on the left side of the screen. Now the wizard's job is to protect the princesses from demons that appear in the sky and descends towards the sea. To shoot down the demons the wizard uses his wand. The controls are simple with two buttons used to rotate the wand while another is used for shooting. The magic is limited though and once used up there is no way to take down the attackers. After all demons have been killed the player earns bonus points depending on how many of the princesses remain standing. A new and tougher wave of demons will then appear.

sample_screenshots.caption: Getting points for those girls saved

title: The Wizard

description:
Ogles is a pattern matching action puzzle game. Down the bottom of the screen are a number of columns and above these LEGO blocks (here called ogles) in various colours move back and forth. When starting out the right most column is filled with blocks and the player's task is to recreate this stack in the corresponding column on the left side of the screen. This is done by controlling a dog called Flash and picking up the right blocks and then dropping these in the right column. If a block is dropped in the wrong column it will automatically be dumped into a bin. Once the stack has fully been recreated the game moves on to the next level which features one extra stack to recreate.

There are two difficulty levels: one for younger persons and one for older persons. The difference lie in that the second level is played against a clock and features a scoring system. Each correctly placed block is worth ten points while a block dumped into the bin leads to twenty points being decreased. When completing a level ten time the number left on the clock is given in extra points.

sample_screenshots.caption: Drop them in the right column
Wrong ones end up in the bin

title: Ogles

description: Protector is an action game played from a top down perspective that can only be controlled with joystick. In the middle of the screen lies a number of pods and it's the player's objective to protect these from thieves that try to nick them. To stop a thief the player simply rams them by moving his ship over them. Double points are awarded if the thieves are killed after they have picked up pods and are leaving the screen. In addition to the thieves there are other things to watch out for. There are monsters that kills the player upon contact and there are UFOs that drop mines that also can kill the player. The UFOs themselves can however be taken out in the same way as the thieves. Once all thieves have been killed the game moves on to the next level which features more enemies. The player has three lives and when they are gone or all pods have been stolen the game is over.
title: Protector

description:
Microbe is a fixed screen shoot 'em up where Earth once again is being threatened by an alien attack. What's different this time however is that the battle takes place inside the alien. After all attempts with conventional weapons have failed a micro organism is entering the alien's bloodstream in an attempt to kill it from within.

The player takes control of the microbe (which looks more like some sort of insect) and shoots at the various cells, antibodies, aminos and spores inside the alien. The microbe can be moved left and right but also up and down. Each level has its own enemies with its own appearance and movement pattern. In addition to blasting away at the enemies the player also has to watch out for the projectiles that they drop. The player has three lives and when they are used up the game is over.
title: Microbe

description: Heist is a single screen platform game where the player takes control of a bank manager who's task it is to return all the money bags to the vault at the base floor. The bank consists of a number of floors connected with ladders and the money bags are scattered all around it. There is a problem though, as four burglars have made it into the bank and are now trying to catch the player so that they can get away with the cash. The thieves also plant bombs at random occasions and when they do the player only has ten seconds to reach it and disarm it before it blows up. If it does or if the player is touched by one of the intruders a life will be lost. In the bank there are two hammers that can be used to knock out the burglars and they'll be stunned for a random amount of time. They can however only be used on the floor that they are picked up and cannot be carried at the same time as a money bag. A level is completed when all bags have been transferred to the vault and a short sequence is shown before the bank reopens the next day with more skilled burglars.
title: Heist

description:
Karl has inherited a disused treasure mine from an uncle. However as he enter the mine everything goes wrong and a rock fall causes the entrance to be blocked with no other exit in sight. He soon finds that collecting all the boxes in a cavern automatically transports him to the next one. Now it's up to the player to help him do this by guiding him through all the game's thirty caverns.

Karls Kavern is a platformer in the style of Manic Miner. It consists of thirty single screen levels where the objective in each is to simply collect all the boxes that lies scattered around. To make it the player has to jump between platforms (including moving ones) and avoid getting touched by any of the dangers that exist in the underground. Any contact will lead to a loss of life and so will a long fall. Part of the levels are also collapsing platforms and conveyor belts. The player has five lives and when they are all used up the game ends.

In addition to playing all the levels in sequence there is also a practice mode that allows the player to try out all the levels except the last one.
title: Karls Kavern

description: Space Intruders is a clone of the popular arcade game Space Invaders for the BBC Micro, where the object is to navigate your ship left or right, using its built-in laser fire to destroy five rows of aliens who work their way down towards you. If any of these aliens make contact with the ship, a life will be lost. Four bases are there to protect your ship, but these bases can be destroyed piece by piece. From time to time, a UFO will make its way across the screen; and shooting it will award you with bonus points. The game ends when all lives have been lost.

sample_screenshots.caption: Shoot the UFO for bonus points

title: Intruders

description: Apple Pie is a single screen action game where the player controls a tank and has to kill invading aliens. The setting is an American village which is being attacked by waves of aliens who attempt to steal the stars of the national flag. The player's task is to stop them by shooting them before they reach the bottom of the screen where the flag is located. The game is played in a grid-like maze which is viewed from a top down perspective. The tank can be moved forward and turn left and right but only at junctions between buildings. The player has three lives but loses one when colliding with an alien or getting shot. A life is also lost when driving over the flag or letting the aliens get away with all the stars.
title: Apple Pie

description:
Bismarck: Death of a Battleship is a wargame based on the Operation Rheinübung which took place in the North Atlantic Ocean in May 1941. The game can be played by one or two players. In the single player game the player commands the Allied fleet while the computer controls the German. In the two player game the second player controls the German forces. The objective for the Allies is to sink the German ships Bismarck and Prinz Eugen before they can escape to Brest on the French coast while at the same time bring Allied convoys to safety. The objective of the German player is to sink as many enemy ships as possible and reach Brest with the ships.

The game is turn based with each turn representing four hours. A turn may contain four phases: movement phase, update phase, sighting phase and battle phase. The first two happen on every turn. In the movement phase the player issue instructions to units by entering the coordinates they should move to. In the update phase the computer changes the status and positions of all units. In the sighting phase the player can enter battle orders if units of both sides are in the same sector. The battle phase will then be entered and the player can give orders to units to engage, ignore, withdraw or to shadow.

There is also an alternative scenario that takes place in September 1941. It's based on a fictitious history line where Bismarck and Prinz Eugen have made it safely to Brest. The AI player will here attempt to bring the ships back to Germany by moving them through the Atlantic and the player's task is to stop and sink them. In the two player mode the second player controls the German ships. The alternative scenario is played on the same map but some of the units available are different.

sample_screenshots.caption: Here's were we can enter attack orders

title: Bismarck: Death of a Battleship

description:
L: A Mathemagical Adventure is an educational text adventure game that contains mathematical and logical puzzles. The game begins with the player character finding himself outside an old palace. A man dressed as an abbot appears and enters the palace. If the player follows him he will ask for help in finding a girl called Runia who has been captured by the palace's Grey Dogos.

From there on the player navigates the palace in search for the missing girl by entering the typical text adventure commands: north, south, up, down etc to move between rooms and verb/noun combinations to interact with the environment. At times Drogo robot guards will appear and to get pass them the player has to enter the correct number, which is the square root of the number that is written on their chests. Other puzzles involve turning on spotlights in the correct colours by pulling accompanying switches, filing a key to fit four different key holes and planting nine trees so that there are ten rows with three trees in each row.
title: L: A Mathemagical Adventure

description:
Sinbad is an action game that is very loosely based on the stories about Sinbad the Sailor. It consists of two stages each with completely different gameplay.

The first one is viewed from the side and the task here is to convert Sinbad's enemies to a peaceful way of life. A magic carpet with a rope ladder attached to it as well as a number of enemies are moving all around the screen. Sinbad converts the enemies by touching them but to be able to reach them he has to jump up and climb the ladder. However after they have been converted making contact with them again will lead to Sinbad falling off the ladder which makes it increasingly harder to reach the remaining enemies.

When all enemies have been converted the game moves on to the second stage where Sinbad sits on the magic carpet and flies through space. This stage is played from a behind the back view of Sinbad and the task is to fly past the numerous asteroids that appear without getting hit. It's also necessary to avoid flying to high or into the atmosphere since that will lead to energy being drained. If too much energy is lost the game will end. The time that the player has to stay alive for in the second stage is the same as the time needed to complete the first stage.

sample_screenshots.caption: Trying to jump up again after falling
The third one though has different enemies
There is also a spider that should be avoided

title: Sinbad

description:
Cosmic Battlezones is a collection of three Ultimate games for the BBC Micro, containing the following games:

  • Alien 8
  • Jetpac
  • Lunar Jetman

The BBC Micro version of Lunar Jetman is exclusive to this release and was not available separately. There is no joystick option for this version of the game.
title: Cosmic Battlezones

description:
Unbelievable!" Ultimate is a compilation containing the following four BBC Micro games by Ultimate Play The Game:

  • Jetpac
  • Sabre Wulf
  • Knight Lore
  • Nightshade
title: Unbelievable! Ultimate

description:
Q-Master is an eight ball pool game for one or two players. The game is played from a top down perspective and uses keyboard controls. Taking a shot is done in two steps. In the first one the player sets the direction by moving a cross hair around the table while in the second the spin is set by moving a cross hair over the ball. The player can also increase and decrease the power and cue angle. When done pressing return takes the shot. When setting up a game it's possible to choose the level of the AI and the number of frames to be played.

In addition to the main eight ball mode there are three other game variations available. The practice session is a free mode without any rules where the player can rack balls and are able to pick up any ball at any time. The high speed attempt mode is a timed game where the player has to pot all balls on the table as quickly as possible to get a high score. Finally, in the high break attempt mode the player has to pot as many balls in a row as possible.
title: Q-Master

description: Cavey is a fixed screen shoot 'em up with a prehistoric setting. The game takes place in the Valley of the Doomed and the player is in control of a caveman who is being attacked by swarming pterodactyls. The player can move along the bottom of the valley and throw spears at the pterodactyls that fly around at the top of the screen. The pterodactyls will attempt to kill the caveman by dropping rocks that have to be avoided. To kill the attackers the player throws spears which there are five off on the ground and a new has to be picked up after every throw. Pterodactyls that are killed falls to the ground and can kill the player upon contact. When being hit one of three lives are lost.
title: Cavey

description:
Islandia is a strategy game for two to four players. Each player is in charge of a trading company and the aim of the game is to generate wealth by gaining control of islands. All players start out with their own home port at a large island called Islandia. Surrounding it are twelve other islands. Each have a port and produces food, iron and wood at different quantities. When conquering an island a player's income increases with an amount equal to the wealth of the island.

The game is turn based and the number of turns a game should last is decided at the start. Each turn consists of one economic phase and two movement phases. In the economic phase the players can buy ships, armies and fortifications. There are four ship types: steamships, battleships, explorers and troopships. In the movement phases players move around the ships that they have bought. When bumping into an island explorers can give information on the commodities it produces as well as the wealth and strength of its native population. Attacking other ships can be done only by battleships and steamships and happens when they bump into an enemy. If a ship gets crippled it will be unable to attack and have its movement allowance halved but it can get repaired at a friendly port. Troopships are used to transport armies between islands which is necessary to conquer new islands.

sample_screenshots.caption: Attempting a conquest on island C
Exploring island I with info shown in the top left

title: Islandia

description:
JCB Digger is a game where the player is in control of a JCB 3CX Excavator Loader. It is played from a top down perspective and scrolls in four directions with the player being able to drive the vehicle freely around the islands where it is set. On the islands there are meanies, blob-like creatures that the player has to put to sleep. There are two ways to do so. The first way involve digging holes with the backhoe and as the meanies walk into the hole the player quickly has to fill them again with the shovel. The other way to get rid of one is to use the shovel to push it into a salt water sea. If the player is not careful the meanies might capture the JCB and drive away with it which leads to a life being lost.

Putting eight meanies to sleep leads to a new set appearing. The new ones are of a different colour and are able to pass over landscape that the previous colour could not. In addition to capturing the meanies the player can earn points by shovelling away the landscape. There are three different types of landscape that can be shovelled: undergrowth, marsh and stony ground. When all of the landscape has been cleared from the island the player gets to move on to the another island. There are two islands and the starting one is randomly selected.

sample_screenshots.caption: Pushing a meanie into the ocean

title: JCB Digger

description:
Barrage is an artillery game for two players who take turns playing the game on the same computer. Each player is in control of a gun and has to shoot projectiles at the other. In each battle there are 100 men on each side and the aim is to kill all of the enemies' men. On the screen there are also two cities which have to be avoided since hitting them leads to penalties. The landscape is generated for each new game and during the game it is redrawn as shots create craters in the ground.

The game is keyboard controlled and each player has to enter values for the angle and the velocity of the shot while taking in account the wind speed and direction. Players with more than 35 men in the army will also be asked to set a delta angle and velocity which decides if shots will be spread out or fired in a tight cluster. The number of shots taken depends on how many men the player has left.

sample_screenshots.caption: Hitting a city leads to a penalty

title: Barrage

description:
Acid Drops is a fixed screen shoot 'em up where the player can move left and right along the bottom and shoot at the creatures that fly around the screen. The title's dripping acid comes from a large acid bath located in the centre of the screen and if the player is hit by a drop or the projectiles of the enemies a life will be lost. The player will also die if all acid drops out. There are three different enemies; moths, pods and spinners. Initially there are only moths but if they are hit by acid they will mutate into pods which in turn will become spinners when hit. Spinners require two hits to kill.

The objective of a level is to escape through a gate that is located on the right side of the screen. The gate opens with time which will speed up when an enemy is hit. When the gate is fully opened the game moves on to a second stage where the player has to move through a side scrolling tunnel without crashing. If a crash occurs the player still moves on to the next level but without a point bonus. There are nine levels in total.
title: Acid Drops

description:
Mr. Ee! is a variant of the arcade game Mr. Do! The gameplay is very much the same and features a wizard that has to make tunnels through the earth in an attempt to collect all the cherries. At the same time he has to watch out for the chasing bad guys called umphs who will kill him upon contact. The umphs can be killed by either throwing a crystal ball which bounces around the tunnels until it hits something or by making apples fall down onto them. Only one crystal ball can be used at a time and thereafter the player has to wait for another one to appear.

Umphs that get stuck turns into diggers which can digs its own tunnels through the earth. There are also letter monsters who appear after every 5000 points and each has a letter spelling the word extra. When all five has been killed an extra life is given. Once all umphs have left their base in the centre some food will appear. If it is picked up all enemies will halt in their tracks and instead the maras will appear from the letter monster. The maras eat apples that block their path and when killed they turn into apples. When the letter monster or all the maras have been killed the regular enemies come to live again. A level is completed by either killing all the umphs or by eating all the cherries.

sample_screenshots.caption: Crushing an umph with an apple
Digging through the earth, collecting cherries

title: Mr. Ee!

description: Missile Base is a variant of the arcade game Missile Command. The game works the same with the player being in command of protecting six cities from an assault of missiles. The player has access to three anti missile bases that each contains nine rockets which when fired explodes into fireballs that destroy any missiles within its radius. When playing with keyboard each base is controlled individually while when using joystick the base nearest to the crosshair is used. In addition to the regular missiles there are missiles with multiple war heads and intelligent missiles which avoid the fireballs. There are also enemy satellites and planes that fly across the screen and fire at the cities.
title: Missile Base

description: Challenger is a side scrolling shoot 'em up with similarities to both Scramble and Defender. Like in the former the player flies a spacecraft over a terrain full of enemy installations but like in the latter the player can change direction and fly both left and right. The aim of each level is to clear the ground and this can be done by firing laser bolts straight forward or by dropping bombs. Fuel is limited and has to be refilled by dropping bombs on fuel dumps. If clearing the ground takes too long, the aliens will mutate and come after the player. Other things to look out for are rockets, pips and quads. The quads appear on level 2 and on level 3 they start throwing out pips. A limited supply of shields can be used for protection.

sample_screenshots.caption: Some enemies are hard to reach

title: Challenger

description: Plankwalk is a platform game where the player controls Scaffolding Sid whose planks goes berserk and start moving around. The planks move upwards and the aim of the game is simply to stay alive as long as possible by jumping between the plants and staying on the screen. Being carried to the top, running off the sides and falling to the bottom of the screen leads to a life being lost. Controls are limited to moving left and right, jumping and accelerating. Some monsters will appear and have to be avoided but can be killed by being ran into at high speed. Points can be earned by landing on blocks that the player falls through and by eating cherries. Some special planks exist such as the fake planks which disappear and sloping planks which slope either left or right.
title: Plankwalk

description: Cosmic Kidnap is a variant of the arcade shoot 'em up Cosmic Guerilla. The objective of the game is to prevent aliens from freeing three captives from a prison. As the aliens appear from the sides the player has to shoot them down before they start tearing down the prison. If they manage to reach a prisoner they attempt to take it away and if they succeed the player loses one life. Once all the attackers have been killed the game moves on to the next level. For the third level a bug creature will appear. It is smart enough to follow the player and drop bombs and only a hit on its outer extremities will kill it. The game ends when the player has lost all three lives.
title: Cosmic Kidnap

description: Android Attack is an action game set in a maze where the player is pursued by attacking androids. These can be shot and will require one or several hits to kill. It is also possible to drop land mines and these can then be detonated when enemies pass them by. The player has an energy level that decreases with time. When it runs low the movement slows down and mines cannot be used. To increase the energy the player can eat dots that some enemies leave behind in the maze. Most enemies follow the corridors of the maze but there is also a yellow smiley that can move through walls.
title: Android Attack

description:
The Microbugs is an educational game about computing. A computer has been infected by the titular bugs and it's the player's task to enter the machine and clean out the bugs and repair damaged chips. Initially the player explores the computer by foot and can enter some of the chips. After the first few chips have been repaired the player gets access to a saucer which can be used to fly over the main circuit board. There are eight chips that can be entered and each has its own gameplay:

  • Main Logic Chip: A platform game containing six screens where in each the player has to release and activate a robot. This is done by shooting an electronic beam at the cage it is trapped in and then touch it to activate it before finding a way to the exit. Movable blocks can be pushed around and used to reach higher level and there are also elevators to use.
  • Artist Programming Chip: The player is shown an image that has to be recreated through a simple programming language. It simply involves entering the right numbers for shape and colour, x and y coordinates and the size of the object. The player can then test run the script until it is right.
  • Binary Character Definer Chip: The player is shown a grid and has to for each line enter the combined binary value of the squares that are shaded. For example if the three right most squares are shaded a value of 7 (4+2+1) has to be entered.
  • Boolean Programming Chip: The player has to open a number of doors by turning on the wires that go to their control boxes. The screen will show a number of electronic gates (AND, EOR and NAND) which the player interacts with by turning on the correct wires that lead into them.
  • Disk Control Chip: The player has to trap one of the bugs by connecting broken wires. It works similar to a sliding puzzle game where each row or column of the grid can be moved either horizontally or vertically.
  • Typesetting (Newspaper) Chip: The player has to put together news pages by combing boxes in different shapes and sizes with pieces of text. The boxes has to be placed on the page like in a jigsaw puzzle and then the pieces of text that match the sizes of the boxes have to be combined.
  • Modem Communications Chip: The final bug has to be trapped by guiding two robots through a maze. The maze is seen from both a first person and top down view and the aim is to move the robots so that the bug gets chased into one of three traps.

sample_screenshots.caption: Shooting a beam at the trapped robot

title: The Microbugs

description:
Lazer Cycle is a variation of the light cycle section of the arcade game Tron, influenced by the light cycle scene from the move of the same name.

The premise as that in the 25th century artificial intelligence has taken over and pits humans in a barbaric fight to the death on lazer cycles that leave a deadly lazer trail in their wake. A player needs to force the opposing cycles into a wall or its trail in order to eliminate them.
title: Lazer Cycle

description:
Duck is a fixed screen shoot 'em up influenced by the likes of Space Invaders and Galaxians.

Instead of alien invaders and rocket ships we have farmer Tubby and the ducks that try to hit him on the head. Occasionally a swan flies over at the top of the screen that can be hit for a bonus.

By the second level the ducks start to lay eggs that if get to the ground will hatch new ducks that take flight and bounce around the screen.
title: Duck!

description: Inspired in part by Dig Dug with a dash of Boulder Dash where the objective is to collect gold nuggets randomly strew around the underground. Dastardly "misers" chase you around that can be crushed for points by dropping rocks on them. There are six differently coloured misers that each behave differently and require different tactics to handle.
title: Gold Digger

description: Whispy Wood is an educational text adventure game where the player takes the role of a caterpillar exploring a forest. The program is in two parts. Part 1 is purely explorative with the player moving from screen to screen by entering directions of movement. Each screen has text describing the surroundings as well as some graphics. Part 2 is called The Test of Fellowship and adds various dangers with multiple ways for the caterpillar to get killed (e.g. getting eaten by a predator or drowning in a pond). Interacting with the game is done with the following commands: climb, dig, still, wriggle, eat, sniff, listen, hide, bristle, scream as well as directional commands (N, S, E, W).

sample_screenshots.caption: Trying to hide from a dormouse

title: Whispy Wood

description: Crystal Castle is a platform game originally developed in 1984 but never released until 2002. It consists of 64 flip-screen rooms linked together horizontally and/or vertically with some freedom of exploration. The player controls a character that needs to collect all crystals located inside and outside a castle to win the game. The character can be moved left or right, and jump. He can also climb ladders. There are enemies and hazards such as pits to avoid. The character has nine lives. There are three game speeds and the game keeps track of the high score.
title: Crystal Castle

sample_screenshots.caption: The introduction plays a song on Melvyn Wright's Music Machine.
Title screen and starting screen selection.

description:
AstroBlaster is a faithful, but unofficial recreation of the Sega arcade game Astro Blaster, including an eighth sector that was visible in the arcade attract mode, but unreachable in game. In order to fit the game into the limited memory of the BBC Micro, the docking sequence had to be sacrificed.

The player controls a ship at the bottom of the screen, with different squadrons of aliens on the upper half. The objective is to clear the sector of aliens and dock with the mothership. The ship can activate a one use time warp that slows the aliens down for a short while while maintaining its own speed and firepower. The ship's lasers have a temperature gauge, if the lasers overheat they need to be cooled down before they can fire, also at the bottom of the screen there is a fuel meter that measures the fuel consumption of the craft.

There are eight increasingly difficult sectors in total, each sector has different squadrons of aliens. In the original game once a sector is cleared, an asteroid belt is encountered. The asteroids had to be avoided while shooting fireballs that replenish fuel. With the missing docking sequence that replenished the fuel, all asteroids are now fireballs instead and running out of fuel results in a loss of life rather than game over.
title: AstroBlaster

description:
Geordie Racer is an educational game developed for the BBC, based upon the BBC drama series Look and Read installment by the same name. The game features multiple stages of educational puzzles based on characters from the TV show, including the mascot, Wordy and the villain Baz.

The show focuses on both human races and pigeon races in Newcastle upon Tyne in the United Kingdom. In the game the player picks a pigeon to guide through the adventure and attempts to find stolen treasure along the way. The human race element is also featured in one of the sections.

sample_screenshots.caption: Baz attempts to escape in his boat. Search the caves for a way to stop him.
The show mascot, Wordy, introduces the controls.
Struck by lightning! This section is trial and error to find the proper path.
After choosing a pigeon do a math problem to proceed.
The pigeon has returned home but Baz has locked the door!

title: Geordie Racer

sample_screenshots.caption: Lots of Enemies and a Barrier

description:
Aviator is a 1-player flight simulator for the BBC Micro.

The player find themselves in the cockpit of a Spitfire Mark II single seater fighter from the 1940s. The player controls the brakes, engine power, and flaps of the aircraft. The player maneuvers the aircraft by controlling the aileron in 4 directions and moving the rudder left or right. The cockpit includes air speed indicator, vertical speed indicator, slip indicator, compass, engine power, and an artificial horizon. During flight, the player can gain points by flying under a bridge or shooting enemy spacecraft.
title: Aviator

description:
This add-on for the original BBC version of Revs adds four additional tracks to the original's Silverstone:

  • Brands Hatch
  • Donington Park
  • Oulton Park
  • Snetterton
title: Revs 4 Tracks

description: This compilation bundles the original Revs with the 4 Tracks add-on.
title: Revs Plus Revs 4 Tracks

description:
Star Trek Adventure is an unlicensed text adventure based on the classic television series. The player controls Captain Kirk, who finds himself alone on the bridge of the Starship Enterprise. Klingons have attacked and heavily damaged the vessel. The crew has abandoned ship, whilst first officer Spock has beamed over to the Klingon vessel to negotiate a truce, but was imprisoned instead. Kirk now must find a way to repair his ship and rescue Spock, a task which will require infiltrating the enemy vessel as well as visiting a strange alien planet.

The game is controlled via a simple verb-noun text parser. The current room's description is always at the top of the screen, and local objects as well as possible exits are always displayed as well.
title: Star Trek Adventure

description:
Games Compendium is a collection of three games for the BBC Micro.

  • Bomber: The player drops bombs from a plane that moves across the screen, and moves down each trip. The player defines descent speed, plane speed, and building height. The goal is to destroy all buildings to create a safe landing strip before crashing into a building.
  • Boot Hill: Two cowboys face off to shoot the other. The cowboys can move up, down, and can shoot horizontally or 45 degrees up or down. Cacti block shots, but can be destroyed. Each player scores points when they shoot the enemy, and the player with the most points at 200 seconds is the winner.
  • Mole!: The goal is to prevent the black moles from eating all the peanuts, while avoiding the white mole that chases the player. The player defeats a mole by standing beside it and hitting it with a hammer. There are seven levels of difficulty. If all peanuts are eaten, it's game over.
title: Games Compendium

description:
Games Compendium is a compilation of four simple arcade games for the BBC Micro.

  • ABC Puzzle: 4 x 4 sliding block puzzle with the letters A to O. The game records the number of moves and time to solve the puzzle.
  • Fireman!: The player controls a trampoline that can be placed in three separate positions. People jump out of the burning building at the left, and the player must bounce them into the waiting ambulance at the right.
  • Hangman: The player must guess the word from the displayed blanks, or the hangman will fall into a vat of shark-infested custard.
  • Simon: Memory game where the player must memorize and repeat the order that four colored lights are displayed on the screen.
title: Games Compendium

description:
Dragon Rider is a 1-player arcade game for the BBC Micro.

Deep within their clifftop lair, the player anxiously awaits the onslaught of the alien wyrms. Beside the player rests their ancient and noble dragon steed. Suddenly the alarm rings out.

The player chooses from 1–5 dragons per game. The dragon is armed with a laser lance that uses limited energy, has unlimited range, but can only destroy one wyrm at a time. The second weapon is the dragon's fiery breath, which can kill a number of worms at a time, but has a limited range and uses a large amount of energy. The goal is to prevent the wyrms from reaching the bottom of the screen, where they destroy anything they hit. If the player is hit by the wyrm, the player takes damage, and too much damage the dragon loses a life. The dragon replenishes their energy by feeding on the magenta firestones positioned on the valley floor. The dragon skin color reflects its current energy level.
title: Dragon Rider

description:
Tanks! is a 2-player artillery game for the BBC Micro.

Each player controls a tank that can drive a short distance, and fire upon their opponent on the other side of the screen. The player sets the angle and velocity of each attack, and the animated shot arcs across the screen destroying the enemy tank or leaving an impassable crater. The player can set wind characteristics which modify firing. Points are scored for each enemy tank destroyed.
title: Tanks!

description:
Eagle is a 1-player space-themed arcade game for the BBC Micro.

The player is now a member of the elite corps known as the Intergalactic Geologists. The moons of the planet Thrug have been said to contain large amounts of rare trace elements, but the treacherous asteroid belts and lethal underground passages have made it impossible to send a remote probe to survey. The player must pilot an Eagle Automatic Survey Ship through the moons.

The player's ship can move left, right, and accelerate upwards, while gravity continues to accelerate the ship downwards. Iridium pods replenish a small amount of the ship's energy by passing over them. Hitting any obstacles during descent will cost the player's energy, and it's game over if energy reaches 0. Shields can be deployed for a short period of time to reduce damage at the cost of energy.
title: Eagle

description:
Guy in the Hat is a 1-player game for the BBC Micro.

Moving in a hexagonal grid, the Guy in the Hat tries to eat biscuits and avoid the Bickie Bashers. After moving off a hexagon it may change color, and monsters can not enter these squares. The player loses a life if they move on a full square or a monster. Once the Guy in the Hat has eaten his fill of biscuits for the level, the player moves onto the next challenge. The player starts with a total of three lives.
title: Guy in the Hat

description:
Secret Sam 1 is a text adventure for the BBC Micro.

The player takes on the role of Secret Sam, as he tries to find and defuse the A-bomb being deployed by a terrorist organization. Secret Sam must safely navigate MI-6 headquarters, board a plane, infiltrate the terrorist base, and save the day. All commands are via VERB NOUN entry, and no abbreviations are permitted. There is no save/restore feature.
title: Secret Sam 1

description:
Banana Man is a 1-player arcade game for the BBC Micro.

Banana Man must eat 40 banana sandwiches on a 9 x 7 grid in one minute. Peeled bananas are worth two points, and the player can either gain or lose points if they attack Ethel the Cat. If the player lands on the spider or are completely surrounded by appearing blue blocks, then they lose a life. When the grid briefly disappears the player can shuffle squares around.
title: Banana Man

description: Banana Man / Secret Sam 1 is a compilation title containing Banana Man and Secret Sam 1.
title: Banana Man / Secret Sam 1

description: Secret Sam 2 is a spy-themed text adventure for the BBC Micro. The player must explore the buildings and back alleys of London to find and photograph the secret documents desired by the British government. All commands are via VERB NOUN entry, and there is no save/restore feature.
title: Secret Sam 2

description: Guy in the Hat / Secret Sam 2 is a compilation of 2 previously released games, Guy in the Hat and Secret Sam 2.
title: Guy in the Hat / Secret Sam 2

description:
Spooksville is a 1-player horror-themed action game for multiple systems.

Many centuries ago, the All-Powerful Spellbook was stolen from the Great Magician by Count Dracula. Since then, it has laid deep in the darkness of Spooksville, the notorious town where all manners of evil creatures roam. The Spellbook's magic can only be used every 500 years, and it's only weeks before this time arrives. As Gaston the Intrepid and Famous Adventurer, the player must enter Spooksville, defeat the evil creatures within, and recover the magic book.

Gaston can move laterally, jump, climb ropes and ladders, and can also shoot magic spells in a total of eight directions. As Gaston moves between rooms, he can gather a number of items to help him on his quest, holding up to three items at a time. The ring and scroll will also help the player if located. Large bosses require special items to destroy, and some items must be used to solve specific puzzles. The player starts with 100 health points, and these are lost when encountering enemies.
title: Spooksville

description:
Q-Man's Brother is a 1-player arcade game for the BBC Micro.

The brother of Q-Man is now ready to go on his own adventure. Q-man's brother moves about the isometric maze trying to to change the color of all the squares before time runs out. Opposing him are deadly paint pots and paint rollers that appear in the sections of the maze and move downwards. The pots and rollers cost the player a life if they contact, and the paint rollers remove areas previously colored.

The player is armed with three smart bombs per life that temporarily remove the enemies from the screen; they start the game with three lives.
title: Q-Man's Brother

description:
Q-Man is a 1-player Q*Bert clone for the BBC Micro.

Q-Man attempts to color all the blocks on a pyramid by jumping between spaces. Each block landed on changes color. Enemies appear at the top block, and move down, falling off the bottom of the pyramid.

Q-Man can hyperspace between different locations on the pyramid, but this can cost a life. The player is armed with smart bombs, three per life, that can be used to temporarily eliminate the enemy on the screen. If Q-man falls off the pyramid or connects with an enemy he loses a life.
title: Q-Man

description: 3D Munchy / Hangman is a compilation containing the previously released 3D Munchy and a Hangman game.
title: 3D Munchy / Hangman

description:
Play it Again Sam 4 is a compilation of three previously released titles for the BBC Micro, as well as Cosmic Camouflage, which was newly released on this compilation.

  • Cosmic Camouflage
  • Frak!
  • Grand Prix Construction Set
  • Spellbinder
title: Play it Again Sam 4

description:
Grand Prix Construction Set is a 1–2 player race track construction and racing game for the BBC Micro.

The player can create their own racetrack including chicanes, straights, fast bends, sharp bends, and humpback bridges. There are also a number of prebuilt tracks based upon famous real racetracks.

Before each race the player chooses the number of laps and whether to compete against a human or computer opponent. Both cars are shown as a horizontal split screen. There are five levels of computer opponent. Races occur from the perspective behind the cars, and cars can accelerate, brake, and steer left and right. If the player hits a barrier or another car too fast they are destroyed, and the other racer wins.
title: Grand Prix Construction Set

description:
Imogen is a 1-player arcade game with puzzle elements for the BBC Micro.

When the townspeople of Egmain were besieged by a monstrous fire-breathing dragon, they called for the assistance of Imogen, a local wizard with powers of metamorphosis. Responding to this threat, he transformed himself into a more powerful dragon, and quickly slayed the enemy.

Unfortunately, this strain caused his mind to snap when he returned to human form, using his power to burn the townspeople's homes and crops. The Great Wizard thus designed a prison filled with 16 pieces of a magic spell designed to allow Imogen to release himself once his sanity had returned. Imogen was secured, and now his quest for freedom has begun.

Imogen has the ability to turn himself into a monkey, a cat, or return to his human form. As a wizard, Imogen can walk left and right, and jump a short distance, and pick up, use, and manipulate items. As a monkey, Imogen can jump on the spot and climb ropes. As a cat, Imogen can jump a greater distance than the monkey or human form.

Games can be saved in progress, and a password feature allows the player to move to certain parts of the dungeon. Certain objects can be picked up and used at different locations if they are positioned in the wizard's hands.

sample_screenshots.caption: There's a Piece of the Magic Spell
There's a Bow and Arrow up There

title: Imogen

description:
Play it Again Sam 5 is a compilation of previously released BBC Micro games.

  • Bug Blaster
  • Elixir
  • Fortress
  • Imogen
title: Play it Again Sam 5

description:
Play it Again Sam 6 is a compilation for the BBC Micro containing the following:

  • Galaforce 2
  • Hopper
  • Hunchback
  • Sentinel
title: Play it Again Sam 6

description:
Castle Quest is a 1-player arcade game with puzzle elements for the BBC Micro.

The player must explore the castle in search of the wizard's treasure. The screen scrolls in all directions, and the player can move left, right, climb ladders, and jump.

Various items to help solve puzzles can be found, including: a stool, a sword, a wand, a bucket, several torches, a ruby, and an aqualung. The player can pick up these items, and also throw them a short distance. Up to three items can be stored in the player's backpack at a time. A number of dangerous creatures including castle guards, trolls, spiders, and a wicked witch must be outsmarted or avoided.
title: Castle Quest

description:
Starfleet Encounter is a 2–8 player space-themed strategy game for the BBC Micro.

Each player takes the role of supreme leader of a race of space-faring people. The galaxy is divided into eight star systems, each mapped to a 26 x 16 grid containing five planets. Each race has a single mothership that is responsible for all new spaceship construction. The mothership can be damaged and repaired but, if destroyed, that race is eliminated. Each turn is timed, and players can make as many moves as possible during the allotted period.

Each player can create up to eight separate fleets of freighters, scouts, and cruisers. Cruisers are expensive powerful battle ships, freighters allow mining of resources from planets, and scouts allow prospecting of distant areas. Planets can be mined for fossil fuels, radioactive isotopes, and rare metals, which are brought back to the mothership to allow for construction of new ships. As ships move through space they can encounter meteor storms damaging the vessels, or black holes which throw the fleet randomly through the galaxy.

When two or three fleets of opposing races occupy the same sector combat can occur. The aggressor vessel can try to retreat at any time, but may occur more damage by doing so.
title: Starfleet Encounter

description:
Dune Rider is a 1-player Moon Patrol clone for the BBC Micro.

The player is a galactic courier, commissioned by the people of Zennon to run the blockade of aliens besieging their planet with documents vital to the planet's defense. Controlling a dune rider, the player can jump, move forwards and backwards, and shoot vertically or straight ahead while avoiding incoming alien dangers.

The dune rider has limited fuel, which is obtained by destroying larger alien vessels. The player must also jump over lava pits, and shoot radioactive rocks before they are safe to jump. The player starts with three lives.
title: Dune Rider

description:
Plutonium Plunder is a 1-player arcade game for the BBC Micro.

The goal on each level is to push the three cannisters of plutonium behind the opening and closing safety barrier at the top center of the screen before time expires. The player can move in the cardinal directions and shoot directly forwards a short distance.

The player can also break hexoid pods, or push them towards enemies. If enemies are shot they are temporarily stunned. The player is chased by gnomes, who crush hexoid pods. They can be destroyed by hitting them with pods or pushing plutonium over them. Nuclids are large radioactive balls that chase the player through walls. They can not be defeated, only stunned.

The levels are surrounded by electrified walls, bringing instant death if touched. If a hexoid pod hits a wall, it bounces back and kills the player. The player starts with three lives.

sample_screenshots.caption: Not a Lot to Defend Myself With

title: Plutonium Plunder

description:
Demon Decorator is a 1-player arcade game for the BBC Micro.

Chased by a demon octopus, the player controls a paint roller trying to color in all lines of a 6 x 7 grid. The roller moves along lines, and when a level begins only the edges of the screen have paint. The player must start at an active section, and can draw up to three line segments before running out of paint. If this happens, the lines painted are lost. If the player completes a small rectangle they receive points, and the edges of the rectangle become active.

A level is complete when all rectangles are filled. The octopus chases the player around each level, costing a life if it catches up. Every level the octopus moves faster. The player starts with three smart bombs which temporarily stun the octopus. More can be picked up on the maze. When a level is completed, the player is awarded one life and one smart bomb.
title: Demon Decorator

description:
Beeb-Tote is a 1–6 player horse racing gambling game for the BBC Micro.

Each player starts with £1000, and bets on a six horse race. Each player is given a minimal stake per bet and a goal target to win the game. The six named horses have individual odds and are given a form. Each player can bet to win, place, or each way on a single horse. An animated race then takes place and positions are decided. The first player to reach their target, or the last player to lose all their money, is the winner.
title: Beeb-Tote

description:
Caveman Adventure is a text adventure for multiple systems.

The player must guide a Neanderthal caveman separated from his tribe back to his village. Starting in their cave, the player can pick up a number of items to help them survive the wilderness. The player must avoid environmental hazards, fight with wild animals, and be threatened by thunderstorms.

All commands are via VERB NOUN entry. There is no save/restore feature.
title: Caveman Adventure

description:
Labyrinths of La Coshe is a text adventure for the BBC Micro.

The player enters the Labyrinth in search of treasure they must bring back to the starting grotto. During their adventure they face a troll, a cyclops, and a thief. The player must solve mechanical puzzles, adventure through Hades itself, while all the time carefully managing the limited fuel for their brass lamp.

All commands are via VERB NOUN entry, and the goal is to find all treasure in under 136 turns to reach the title of Grotto Master.
title: Labyrinths of La Coshe

description:
The Peter Scott Trilogy is a collection of three previously unreleased multi-screen, side-view arcade puzzle games for the BBC Micro.

Network: The object of this game is to construct the Flynche machine by collecting all 20 parts while avoiding or shooting aliens. The player can jump a short distance and fire directly forwards. There are moving platforms, springs, dangerous floors, ladders, elevators, and other dangers to navigate. The game world extends into a large maze over many screens, and teleport machines allow rapid movement. The player has limited health and fire power. They lose a life if health hits 0.

Pandemonium: The object of this game is to collect all 12 pieces of The Core while avoiding or shooting aliens. The player can jump a short distance and fire directly forwards. There are moving platforms, springs, dangerous floors, ladders, elevators, and other dangers to navigate. The game world extends into a large maze over many screens, and teleport machines allow rapid movement. The player has limited health and fire power. They lose a life if health hits 0.

Yoyo: Some hacker with a satellite has caused the player to become trapped inside the computer game they were playing. Yoyo can move left, right, and jump. Yoyo can also temporarily enact a force shield that destroys enemies that contact it. The player has limited energy, but regains this by collecting valves. The goal is to collect every valve over 75 screens. If the player touches an enemy they lose a life, and starts with six lives.
title: The Peter Scott Trilogy
